commitResults.messageTitle: Rewrote code to follow Java Style Guide
Changed variable names and re-formatted "list" command
Submission for Level-3. * Added mark command. * Added unmark command. * Created a new class called "Task". * "list" now displays the status of each task.

commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks can be added through any non-keyword message

We want to create more categories for tasks to add more details
into our list.

Let's create a parent class called Task and create 3 other
subclasses: ToDo, Deadline and, Event.

Using inheritance is preferable because every task shares some
similar properties like a IsDone status and the description of the
task.

There is currently no automated testing in-place.

We want to ensure the Poolsheen program runs as expected without
needing to manually test every time a change is made.

Let's,
* create an input and expected file
* create a runtest.bat file which can be executed to run the tests

The INPUT.txt will be represent the inputs into the program.
The EXPECTED.TXT will be what the program should print and will be
compared with ACTUAL.TXT, the actual lines that our program will
print.

There is currently no handling of edge cases when wrong
or incomplete inputs are entered.

We want Poolsheen to prompt the user on how they can fix their
wrong or incomplete inputs if an error occurs.

Let's,
*create an IncompleteCommandException class for incomplete commands
*create an UnknownCommandException class for unknown commands
*catch runtime errors with IndexOutOfBoundsException
and NumberFormatException
*catch unexpected errors using Exception

The IncompleteCommandException when caught will let the user know
what part of the command they are missing. The
UnknownCommandException lets the user know that the command does not
currently exist.

There is currently no way to remove tasks that a user has
accidentally added into their Poolsheen program.

We want Poolsheen to include a "delete" command to delete a task
of position x from the list of tasks that Poolsheen remembers.

Let's create a new method called deleteTask which removes the task
of position x.

The position x will be fed after the input has been parsed. If
"delete 5" is inputted and the list of tasks has a size greater
than 5, the task of position 5 will be removed.

Commands are now only distinguished by the string commands that
they are assigned to.

We want each command to have a type using the Java enum type.

Let's create a new enum type for each command type.

The switch cases for processing the input will now compare using
the value of the string which will be converted to an enum type if
that enum type exists.
